page.title: 15THE OAK HOUSE, OLDBURY
page.content: The Oak House takes its name from an enormous oak tree, which stood in front of the building until the tree was destroyed by fire in 1800. There is not a record of the builder of the propety, but the Turton family were in residence for most of the 17C. They were active members of the community and during the Civil War supported the Parliamentary forces. In 1894 Alderman Farley bought and restored Oak House and presented it to the town. It operated as a museum until 1951, when it was re-furnished in the style of the 17C. Among the many interesting items to be seen are some old church chests, several long case clocks, an early 17C oak press and a William & Mary oak bureau. Today it is visited by many school parties who are given free guided tours.
